fermi questions.question: The 1936 Berlin Olympics Stadium was later used as a bunker by Nazis during WWII. How many people could it hold?
How many standing lighthouses remain in America?

Consider the amount of time that Steam users logged in 2020 playing video games. If Joel spends that entire amount of time calculating the digits of pi, given the formula of the average time to calculate the nth digit of pi in weeks = n^(1/2), how many digits would he manage to calculate? (He’s not the fastest at calculating these digits).
How many more bicycles are in China than in London?
As of 2021, how many answers have been provided on Stack Overﬂow, the largest coding Q&A site?
What is the 100th Fibonacci number?

How many happy numbers occur from 0 to 1,000,000? A happy number is deﬁned as one where by continuously summing the squares of the digits, one eventually arrives at 1. For example, 13 is happy, because 1^2 + 3^2 = 10, and 1^2 + 0^2 = 1. Assume base 10.
How many of the values in the set of happy numbers from the previous question are prime?
Here are the ﬁrst few Pentagonal numbers. What is the 103212103rd Pentagonal number?
What is the sum of the answers to the ﬁrst four Math section problems?
answers: Sum of the previous four answers

fermi questions.question: What is the product of the answers to the ﬁrst four Math section problems?
answers: Product of the previous four answers

fermi questions.question: Let the correct answers to question 1, 2, 3, and 4 of the Math section be a, b, c, and d, respectively. What is a^b^c^d?
answers: a to the power of b to the power of c to the power of d

fermi questions.question: How many cans of Campbell’s chicken noodle soup will it take to fill up an Olympic-sized swimming pool?
Consider the label of standard soup can. How many labels laid in a line would it take to circumnavigate the equator? (Assuming the labels float on top of the oceans)
Soup cans are made of tin-coated steel. How many cans would need to be melted to form a 1-by-1-by-1 meter solid cube?
Chinese bird drop soup is made from a species called the edible-nest swiftlet (Aerodramus fuciphagus). How many of these birds are there in Asia?
How much sodium (in mg) is in a 24-pack of Maruchan chicken ramen?
How many units (cans) of soup are sold each year in the United States?
Consider placing soup cans upright in a hexagonal region from a bird’s eye view. How many can fit in a regular hexagonal region with side lengths of 1 mile?

How many milliliters of water would need to be boiled to cook enough ramen cups to feed each and every college student in the U.S.? Each ramen cup should be filled to the brim with water and each college student eats 1 package.
How much gross profit, in USD, has the Campbell’s soup company made since 2000?

Consider throwing a soup can using a cannon with an angle of elevation of 30 degrees. Considering the earth as flat, at what velocity (in meters per second) is it necessary to launch the soup from New York City to Philadelphia?

Eric has a collection of 2023 different types of soup. If he tries a different type of soup each day uniformly at random, how many days would you expect it to take for him to finish trying every type of soup?

You travel in a can-shaped spaceship from earth to Soup Galaxy, which is 7 light years away from earth. You move at approximately 40 percent of the speed of light. Upon arrival, what will the difference in time, in hours, between your clock and a clock back on earth?
How many cans of soup do you need to stack to reach the moon?
A soup can finishes a marathon by rolling straight ahead. How many rotations has the soup can completed?
A ladle is a wonderful device for serving soup. Suppose you wanted to serve the ocean; how many scoops would it take to empty the ocean?

Andrew, a notable soup scholar, decides to write a definitive guide to the history of soup. He ends up with a text with about as many words as the Bible. To save on printing costs, he prints in Times News Roman, with size 1 font and double spaced. How many pages does he need to print for one copy of his book?

An empty can of soup is filled with ice and placed outside on a table. Assuming uniform, constant heat from the summer heat, how many seconds would it take for the cylindrical block of ice to completely dissolve.

Penn has instituted a special secret award called the soup scholarship in 2000. Each year, 5 percent of the incoming freshmen class is selected to be a recipient. How many soup scholarships have been awarded up until the end of 2024?

There are many fish, pork, chicken, and beef-based soups leading to so many unique flavours! If we distinguish the animals up to species, how many soup flavours can we generate if each flavour is a combination of two species?
The average U.S. frieght train is 6,500 feet long. How many cans of soup can be packed into this frieght train?
Eric consumes one can of soup each time he cuts his hair. Over the course of 100 lifetimes, how many cans will he consume?
Soup is chemistry. How many compounds are found on pubchem (a chemical information database)?
Soup is served in cafeterias across Penn’s campus every day. How much money is spent on the Dining at Penn department each year?
If I harnessed the energy consumed when every Google employee googles “google” simultaneously, how long could I power a standard hair dryer?
If the Earth, by mass, was comprised entirely of solid silver, what would the acceleration due to gravity be, in m/s^2 ?
If I melted the earth down (from Question above) and sold it, how much money, in Japanese Yen, could I make?
How many packages of party sized Lay’s Sour Cream and Onion Potato Chips would I need to consume in order to equal the amount of Calories burned by a 200 lb man during an ironman triathlon?
If, for every time someone streamed “Cruel Summer” by Taylor Swift on Spotify, Taylor Swift adds an extra floor to the Empire State Building, how tall would the Empire State Building be, in meters?
If I randomly drop a pebble over the United States, what is the probability that my pebble hits a Tesla?
How many fortnights would it take for me to run a marathon, assuming that I run at a pace of 5 smoots/shake?
What is the minimum number of cans of SphagettiOs alphabet soup would I need to reconstruct the book Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone?
How heavy, in kg, would the newest Macbook M2 Pro be if I replaced every single transistor with a can of Campbell’s Chicken Soup?
What is the 200th fibonacci number?
How many digits does 13123456789 have?
How many primes are there less than 10000?
How many gas stations are there in the US?
If the sun and earth both double in size, how long will it take for the earth to go around the sun?

Suppose on the day Jesus was born I got a dollar. Exactly one year later, I got 2 dollars. Every year thereafter I receive twice as much as the year before. I am immortal and quite a hoarder so I don’t spend any money. How much do I have in 2023?

Eric claims that he doesn’t need any meteorology to predict the weather. Darren challenges him with the following game. Darren starts by paying Eric 10^10 dollars, and Eric is to make make daily predictions about whether or not it will rain the following day. Eric is to do this for an entire year, after which Darren will calculate the difference between how many times it rained and how many times Eric said it would rain. We call this difference x, and then Eric must pay Darren x*10 dollars. If Eric plays optimally, what is the maximum amount he can guarantee that he earns (or if he loses money - what is the minimum amount he can lose) at the conclusion of the game?
If the world was scaled down so that the Earth was the size of a standard soccer ball, what would be the volume of Jupiter in liters?
If every person in Madagascar simultaneously ate a bagel, how much heavier, in grams, would Madagascar’s population be?
What is the combined weight, in kg, of every elephant in the world?
Suppose a clock tells the right time exactly 100 times a day. If this clock is used to time an olympic 100m sprint, approximately how fast, in seconds, will the runners be?
In Newtons, how many flicks worth force will it take to break someone’s arm?

Suppose that all the DNA from each cell in a human was stretched out and placed in a single row. How many gallons of gas would it take a 2023 Toyota Prius to drive the distance equal to all of that stretched out DNA?
Niagara falls is an absolutely iconic waterfall. That being said, what is the volumetric flow rate of Niagara Falls in Sverdrups during high season?
How many hydrogen atoms are contained within the water in Lake Superior?
How long would it take, in days, for me to drain all of the Oceans on Earth if I solely drank the recommended amount of water each day from the oceans?
What is the maximum acceptable latency (delay) for international calls as specified by the International Telecoms Union, in quectoseconds?
What would the radius, in meters, of a sphere of solid cheddar cheese need to be before it collapsed into a black hole?
How many oxygen molecules would be inhaled if every single person alive on Earth took a collective breath?
A 1 Joule is equivalent to 1 kg * m^2 * s^-1. What is the value of 1 Joule in the units of (troy ounce) * (furlong^2) * (microseconds)^-1?
I’m currently at the bottom of a set of 30 stairs. I can take the steps 1, 2, or 3 at a time. How many ways can I climb the 30 stairs?
How many digits are in the number 14920?
Let n be the largest integer such that (264)! / 2^n is an integer. What is n?

Rafiki is currently located at coordinates (0, 0) on the Cartesian plane. He’s heard rumors of a legendary stash of bananas buried at points (14,14). He randomly moves right or up along the grid with equal probability. Given that he does reach the stash, what’s the probability that the only times he intersects the line y=x is at (0, 0) and (14, 14)?

Seven Lakes High School is an impressive school with experienced, resilient staff and talented, hardworking students. Let n = the number of Dual Credit and Advanced Placement Courses offered at Seven Lakes High School. Compute n^35.

During my time at Seven Lakes, I’ve picked up a few bad habits, including gambling. My new favorite game, Redjack, costs me 1 dollar to play each time. On my nth consecutive game of Redjack, I have a probability of 1/n of winning 1 dollar in profit, and n−1/n of losing my dollar. If I ever end up with more than 4 dollars, I win and quit gambling. Otherwise, I continue playing indefinitely. I start with 0 dollars and I’m allowed to go into debt as I play. What’s the probability I win?

Frank was born with Multichromasomia. He has 138 chromosomes. He straightens the DNA from all of his cells to form a very thin line. How many of these lines are required to stretch across the Milky Way Galaxy?

If every three days, all of the students in Australia drank a gallon of gasoline and absorbed 38 percent of its chemical energy, how many total kilocalories of gasoline would all of the students in Australia have absorbed in a span of 11 weeks?

Professor Skibidi is a passionate bacteria cell collector. In fact, she is rumored to have an unlimited supply of E. coli hidden in many, many toilets. Assuming that Professor Skibidi reshapes but does not compress each E. coli cell, how many of these cells can she fit in the Earth’s atmosphere?
I have a Copper sulfate solution with a molarity of 0.1. Suppose I mistake it for blue Gatorade. How many milliliters of solution would I have to drink for a lethal dose?
How many tablespoons of blood does the heart of an average person pump in a year?
If the yearly sweat of all Americans were harvested, how many Olympic size swimming pools could it fill?
How fast do fingernails grow (in furlongs per lustrum)?
An average human brain is composed of how many neurons?
An average human brain is composed of how many glial cells?
Aubrey Drake Graham’s latest album, For All The Dogs, amassed more than 500 million on-demand streams in its debut week. How many bones are in all of the living dogs around the world?

Researchers have stumbled across a new moon orbiting the Earth. When viewed from the Earth, this new moon has the same composition and apparent size as the actual Moon but is only half the distance from the Earth. Calculate the magnitude of the gravitational force a person experiences on Earth from this new moon in Newtons.
The speed of light in a vacuum is 299 792 458 m/s. If I were traveling at exactly one m/s slower than the speed of light, how many seconds would go by on Earth during one of my “years?”
What would be the value of Boltzmann’s constant in second-Rankine-Angstrom-gram units? (Rankine is the absolute scale unit of Fahrenheit)
How fast does the fully loaded MSC Irina cargo ship need to be moving (in m/s) in order to remain in circular orbit 10 km above the surface of Earth?
Now if the air resistance is 2 m/s2, and the ship is on fire, how fast does the ship need to burn (in kg/s) in order for the ship to remain at constant velocity?
How many Joules of electrical energy can I extract from a mole of electrons on the surface of a 1628 cannon ball?
How many barber shops are there in Tennessee?
How many barber schools are there in Tennessee?

How much money, in nickels, did the College Board CEO get paid in 2021?
People often complain about the large US military budget. What percent of GDP is the American Military budget?
How much money would it cost to stack bills to the height of the tallest building in Houston? Half of these bills will be 10-dollar bills, and the other half will be 50-dollar bills.
In dimes, how much money has the United States government earned from the sale of its military equipment in fiscal year 2022?
A transaction occurs in Wall Street. How many babies are born until Tokyo knows of the transaction?
Gertrude always rides her motorcycle at a speed of 18 centimeters per millisecond. How long does it take her in minutes to travel from Seattle, Washington to Houston, Texas on her motorcycle?

The Coastline paradox is where the Coastline of a body gets infinitely larger as you add resolution to your count. If we ask NOAA, they tell us that the coastline of Florida is 8436 mi. Estimate the coastline to land area ratio of Florida given this value in mi/mi2
How many named mountains are there in the United States of America?

I’m currently on a quest to become a varsity member of the SLHS Cross Country team. Let X represent the distance I’ll have run when I achieve this. Express X in terms of the length of the U.S.-Canada border.

Suppose the United States government began to cover half of Alaska’s land with exactly 1 layer of Rubik’s cubes as an attempt to eradicate 9-legged snakes. How many Rubik’s cubes are necessary for this initiative?

Samir the snail moves at a velocity twice the average snail; he is very fast for a snail. How long in hours will it take him to travel the length of US Interstate 10, assuming he travels at constant velocity?

I begin digging through the surface of the Earth in a straight line at a rate of 1 m/sec. My speed of digging accelerates at a rate of 1 ft / sec2. Assume I am able to maintain this throughout the dig. How many seconds will it take me to dig to the point on the Earth diametrically opposite to where I started?
How many times would I have to fold a piece of paper to reach the second-closest star to the Earth?

Redshift occurs when a light emitting object is moving away from you at a rapid pace, causing the emitted light to shift in wavelength. The opposite can occur when you are moving towards an object. How fast do you have to be moving, in m/s, for red traffic lights to turn green?
The UNSC Infinity has a Magnetically Accelerated Cannon that fires a 3000 metric ton projectile at 4 percent of the speed of light. How much energy does this projectile carry in kilojoules?

Fusion reactors seem to be the next innovation in clean power generation. The ITER in french is the largest Tokamak reactor currently in construction. We also have a giant fusion reactor in the sky, called the sun. How much more energy does the sun produce compared to ITER’s goal output of 500 MW?

Aliens are on their way to earth to invade, and the only way that the newly formed United Earth Government has thought of to resist is to launch the WWII Era USS Iowa into space to fight the Aliens. If the ship weighs 46,551 long tonnes, how much energy would it take to get the ship moving at orbital velocities (joules)?
How much mass, in kilos, will the sun lose in its lifetime due to nuclear fusion?

What is the mass of the Sun in gigagrams?
What is the total mass of all the asteroids in our solar system, in metric tonnes?
If all the stars in our galaxy were to magically be identical clones of the sun and be lined up next to each other, how many light years would this line extend?

How many medals will be awarded at this tournament?

How much total compensation did the mill pay out to victims of the tragedy, in Kyrgyzstani soms?
How many sunflower seeds would it take to fill up a standard-size 55 gallon steel drum?
How many more sun rays are there on the Kyrgyz flag than on the Kazakh flag?
How many people with the last name Kim are there in Kazakhstan?
How many mountains are located in Tajikistan?

If x, y and z are the number of Cyrillic characters in the Tajik, Kyrgyz and Russian translations of “Lenin Peak” respectively (excluding spaces), how many digits are in the decimal representation of xyz ?
How many times more electrified railway track does Russia (the world’s largest country) have than Canada (the world’s second-largest country)?
What is the equivalent energy of one of these Nippon Sharyo gallery cars in British Thermal Units, using mass-energy equivalence?
If I were to start a nuclear reaction with a stick of butter-sized block of Uranium-235, how much energy would be released in joules?
If I bought two stick of butter-sized blocks on the day you were born, one of Uranium-235 and one of Cobalt-60, how many more grams of uranium would I have today than cobalt?
How many years worth of calorie consumption does a single stick of butter represent for the combined population of the entire Houston metro area?
If every household faucet in Texas were to leak at a rate of 1 drop of water per second, what is the mass of all the water that would be wasted annually, in troy ounces?
If I were to take all the food wasted in the United States annually out of the landfill and put it into several Olympic-sized swimming pools, how many pools would it fill up?
How heavy would all this food waste be, in terms of standard Las Vegas tournament poker chips?
How many unique ways are there to shuffle a “superdeck” consisting of 8 standard 52-card decks?

What is the probability that a randomly drawn 5-card ordered sequence from an 8-card superdeck contains my birthday in MMDDYY format, if aces have a face value of 1 and jacks, kings and queens all have a face value of 11?
How many decks of cards do Las Vegas casinos go through every year?
If I were to stack all of the decks from the previous question on top of each other, how many Vujanovi´cs tall would they be?
Assuming he solved question 23 correctly, by what factor would his answer be off, assuming he answered using decimal (not Fermi) answers?
Please calculate the value of p1# + p2# + ... + p25#
What is 50! divided by p50#?
What is the value of the natural log of the asymptotic growth function of pn# evaluated at n = 10, 000, 000?
As of 1. January 2024, how many mathematical sequences were included in the OEIS?
How many Indo-European languages are there, according to Ethnologue?

What is the sum of the international country calling (ISD) codes of all UN member states whose list of official languages includes the Indo-European language with the largest number of native speakers, either de facto or de jure?
If x is the number of vowels in the village’s name and y is the number of consonants, please calculate the value of x!y!
Please recompute your answer to the previous question, but this time using the Welsh reckoning, where digraphs (such as ng and dd ) are counted as single letters, and w and y are treated as vowels.
How many characters (excluding spaces) are there on the English-language Wikipedia page about Wikipedia?
What were Wikipedia’s total operating expenses for the fiscal year 2022-23?
How many monthly active users does ChatGPT have?
If Kostya cheated on the LSAT by feeding all of the questions into GPT4, how many students from the 2022-23 exam cycle would he score better than?
How many examinees from the previous problem would score better than Tadashi but worse than Kostya?
How many ethnic Japanese live in Russia?

How many fewer characters are there in the original Japanese text of Article 1 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) than in its Polivanov-based Cyrillic transcription, including spaces?

If x represents the median length of a word in the Greenlandic-language text of the UDHR (rounded to the nearest integer), and y represents the number of characters in the Greenlandic translation of the words “Universal Declaration of Human Rights” (excluding spaces), what is xy?
If I were to pick ten people at random from the world population, what’s the probability that at least three of them would be able to speak Greenlandic?

What is the total value of annual Norwegian fish and seafood exports to Japan, in yen?

answers: Sum of both weights in micrograms

fermi questions.question: How many 2x4 lego bricks would it take to equal the volume of the earth.
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. The volume of the Earth is approximately 1.08 x 10^21 m^3. A 2x4 lego is roughly 0.00004 m^3, so it would take roughly 2.7 x 10^25 lego bricks.

fermi questions.question: How many 2022 Toyota Prii (plural for Prius) stacked on top each other would it take to reach the moon.
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. The distance to the moon is approximately 384,400 km.  A Prius is about 1.5 meters tall, so it would take roughly 2.5 x 10^8 Priuses.

fermi questions.question: In September 2022, two Russian gas pipes under the Baltic Sea began to leak methane. Conservative estimates suggest that methane was leaking at a rate of 500 metric tons per hour. Assume this rate is constant. How many cows would it take to “leak” methane at the same rate on average (via farting).
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. The average cow produces about 0.25 kg of methane per day, so the pipes release approximately 1.2 x 10^7 kg per day. Therefore it takes about 4.8 x 10^7 cows

fermi questions.question: How much electricity was consumed in the U.S. in 2021, in kilowatt-hours (kWh)?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. The consumption was around 4 trillion kWh, or 4 x 10^12 kWh

fermi questions.question: Part of First Lady Michelle Obama's Let's Move! Initiative, the 2010 Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act, required school meal providers to limit calories and reduce saturated fat, trans fat and sodium. Consider a man who has 20 kg of body fat when he goes on a hunger strike. Determine how long he can survive on his body fat alone in decades.
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Fat has roughly 9 calories/gram, which is 180,000 calories.  A man consumes about 2000 calories a day. Thus, this would be approximately 90 days, or less than 0.1 decades

fermi questions.question: The use of messenger pigeons dates all the way back to about 3000 BC in Ancient Egypt. They were also notably used by Ghengis Khan to send messages across the vast Mongol Empire, and continued to be used as a regular means of communication as recently as World Wars One and Two. Assume I use a messenger pigeon ﬂying at the average messenger pigeon speed to send a 1080p HD DVD copy of the movie, “Shrek the Third,” from Los Angeles, California to Seattle, Washington. What is the eﬀective data transfer rate of this trip in Megabytes per second.
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. A 1080p HD DVD is roughly 8 GB. Distance is about 1800 km. Pigeons fly about 50 km/hr, so time is 36 hrs, or 130,000 seconds. Transfer rate would be around 0.06 MB/s

fermi questions.question: How many sheets of standard US Letter sized paper would it take to cover the surface of the moon?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Surface area of the moon is 1.4 x 10^13 m^2. Letter paper is about 0.06 m^2, so it takes roughly 2.3 x 10^14 pieces of paper.

fermi questions.question: How many bits of data are in all of Taylor Swift's albums (excluding her upcoming album Midnights) at FM radio quality?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. She has released 9 albums and around 10 songs/album. FM radio is around 128 kb/s. Assume each song is 3 minutes long, or 180 seconds. That makes each song roughly 23,000 kb, or 23 megabits.  Total is about 2 x 10^5 megabits or 2 x 10^11 bits

fermi questions.question: How much would a Boeing 747 weigh in newtons if it's entire interior were ﬁlled with cement?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. A 747 has a volume of around 1000 m^3.  Cement has a density of 2400 kg/m^3, which equals 2,400,000 kg. Weight in newtons is around 2.3 x 10^7 N.

fermi questions.question: If an average human were able to grow out their hair inﬁnitely, how long would they have to grow it in miles for the total mass of the hair on their head to be equal to the mass of an adult plains zebra?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. A zebra weighs around 300 kg. Human hair weighs about 0.00001 kg per cm, so it takes around 3 x 10^7 cm or 300,000 m, or 200 miles

fermi questions.question: What is (1/7) ? 35
answers: This question is unclear, but presumably asks for the 35th digit of the decimal representation of 1/7.  1/7 = 0.142857142857... the repeating block has 6 digits. 35 mod 6 = 5, so the digit is 5

fermi questions.question: How many times will the average human's heart beat in their lifetime?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Average human lifespan is 80 years. Heart beats around 70 times per minute, which is 100000 per day. Thus it is around 2.9 x 10^9 beats

fermi questions.question: How many lightning strikes occur in the United States per year?

fermi questions.question: How many molecules of water are in the average American woman?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Average woman is 60 kg and 60% water or 36 kg of water. Water has molecular weight of 18 g/mol or 0.018 kg/mol.  Moles of water are about 2000, so there are 1.2 x 10^27 molecules

fermi questions.question: The ﬁbonacci sequence is a series of numbers where each number is the sum of the preceding two numbers in the sequence. For example, the series starts with 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21,…. What is the 35th term in this sequence when the ﬁrst 1 is counted as the ﬁrst term?

fermi questions.question: The fashion industry has been booming in the United States. How many square yards of fabric would it take to create Highlands Virtual Invitational shirts for everyone living in America?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. US population is 300 million. Shirts are about 1 square yard, so it takes about 300 million square yards of fabric

fermi questions.question: Salmon is an extremely versatile ﬁsh; aside from being highly nutritious, it is also prepared in various ways around the world. In Japan, salmon can be prepared as sashimi, a delicacy that many enjoy. In 2020, how many tons of salmon was consumed in Japan?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Japan consumed about 200,000 tons of salmon in 2020

fermi questions.question: You decide to crochet a to-scale version of the moon with Bernat, size 6 blanket yarn. Walmart also ran out of stuﬃng, so the entirety of your to-scale crocheted moon is made out of your expensive Bernat yarn. If a skein of yarn is 300 grams for every 200 meters, how heavy will your ﬁnal project be?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. The volume of the moon is 2 x 10^10 km^3 or 2 x 10^19 m^3. Since we don't know how the yarn is packed in, let's assume around 50% packing density. We also assume each yarn is a line and not a filled space. Thus we have 1 x 10^19 m^3 of yarn in total.  Density of yarn is 1.5 g per meter, so we get 1.5 x 10^19 g = 1.5 x 10^16 kg

fermi questions.question: In continuation from the last problem, Bernat yarn is expensive, given its softness and thickness. It's coveted by many crocheters around the world. For reference, every 200 meters costs $10. How much would your to-scale version of the moon cost you?
answers: From last question, we need 1 x 10^19 m^3 of yarn. Since the density is given as per meter, we can't use this volume. If we imagine that the moon is made up of 1 thick yarn, we can say the volume is roughly the surface area times a thickness. The surface area of the moon is around 1.4 * 10^13 m^2. Let's say the yarn is 0.005 meters thick. That is about 7 * 10^10 m^3. The length of a yarn that could fill that volume could be estimated as 7 * 10^10 m^3/ (0.005 m)^2 = 2.8*10^15 m. Each 200 meters is $10, so we have 1.4* 10^13 * $10 which is $1.4*10^14

fermi questions.question: Your tournament directors have an outrageous appetite for Chinese dumplings, speciﬁcally, wontons. In fact, we love wontons so much that we hand minced 1000 pigs worth of meat and wrapped them into wontons. How many wontons did we make with 1000 pigs worth of meat? (deﬁnition of wontons: bite sized dumpling--think of a meatball wrapped in a thin dough-like wrapper)
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. An average pig has 100 kg of meat, so 100,000 kg of meat.  Wontons have about 15g of meat, so there would be roughly 6.7 million wontons

fermi questions.question: Coconut milk is used in lots of South East Asian desserts. However, you decide to go on a diet, and instead of enjoying the coconut milk, you limit yourself to no more than a shot-glass's worth of coconut milk a day. How many days until you would have consumed enough coconut milk to ﬁll an Olympic size swimming pool?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. An olympic sized pool is 2.5 million liters. A shot glass is 50 mL.  It would take 5 x 10^7 days

fermi questions.question: I love sparkling water, more than most beverages. However, whenever I buy a pack, I am often faced with the dilemma that I am buying a can that is partially air. How many balloons can I ﬁll with the gas from a lifetime's worth of sparkling water if I drink 1 a day?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. An average lifespan is 80 years or 29,000 days. A can of seltzer has about 2 liters of gas. A balloon can contain about 5 liters of gas. This yields about 10,000 balloons

fermi questions.question: You drive the best car in the world-- a Toyota Prius. You decide to take a road trip from Omaha, Nebraska, to Irvine, California. How many times would you have to reﬁll your gas tank during your road trip?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Distance is roughly 1700 miles. A Prius gets around 50 miles per gallon and has a 11 gallon tank. You would need to fill up around 3 times

fermi questions.question: Nico Rosberg, the 2016 F1 champion (who beat 7x WDC Lewis Hamilton in the same machinery), has a bad habit of not turning into corners. Every time he does this, he crashes his toyota corolla. How many kitkat bars can I buy with the money lost from new cars if he encounters 3 corners a day for his entire life (not counting the ﬁrst 16 where he couldn't drive)?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Lifespan 80, but 64 years of driving.  Crashes 3 cars per day.  Corollas cost around 20,000 dollars. 2.3 million crashes over a lifetime. That's about 4.6 * 10^10 dollars. Kit kat is 1 dollar, so 4.6 * 10^10 bars

fermi questions.question: All you can eat buﬀets are the best thing in the world--endless amounts of food. How many ounces of food can an average human ﬁt in their stomach before it would (literally) explode?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. Stomach can hold around 1 liter or around 30 oz of food

fermi questions.question: I love bananas. I take out around 4 from the dining hall everyday. If I double my intake from the previous day, every day, for 3 years, what daily value % of potassium would I have on the last day?
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. This is essentially the 2^1095 or 2^1096 depending on whether or not you include the first day. However, potassium amount does not increase linearly with number of bananas. 1 banana contains about 400 mg of potassium and the daily value is 4700 mg, so 1 banana is around 8% daily value.  Each day, if we assume an average banana is 100g, there would be around 400g * 2^1095 bananas on the last day, so the daily value percentage is 2^1095 * 32%. This is incredibly high, and is a very silly question as you'd die before this point

fermi questions.question: Antonio Browns's newest song has been played 454k times. If we dedicated the time spent listening to his "music" to folding origami cranes, how many cranes would we have? Assume you take an average amount of time to fold the ﬁrst crane and that you don't get faster at folding cranes.
answers: This is a Fermi problem and requires estimation. A song is around 3 minutes. 454k * 3 = 1.4 million minutes. Origami crane is 5 minutes. That would be 300,000 cranes

Explain the concept of ecological succession, describe primary succession
answers: Primary succession occurs in an environment in which new substrate is devoid of vegetation and soil, usually lacking organic matter. The most common examples of primary succession are areas that have had lava flows or have been recently deglaciated. The first species to appear are pioneer species, such as lichens, moss, and bacteria, that can break down rock and build up soil. After a long period of time, grasses, shrubs, and trees will eventually appear.

ecology.question: Discuss the concept of "boreal forests" and their role in carbon storage and climate regulation.
answers: Boreal forests, also known as taiga, are vast coniferous forests found in high-latitude regions of the Northern Hemisphere. They are crucial for carbon storage, acting as a significant carbon sink by absorbing CO2 through photosynthesis and storing it in their biomass and soil. This carbon storage helps regulate global climate by mitigating greenhouse gas levels. Additionally, boreal forests play a vital role in climate regulation through evapotranspiration, which influences regional precipitation patterns and temperature.

ecology.question: What is anthropogenic food?

answers: Sustainability: The methods used to create Terra Preta are seen as sustainable agricultural practices that can improve soil health, enhance crop yields, and sequester carbon, thus mitigating climate change.

ecology.question: How is the fertility of Terra Preta?
answers: High Fertility: Unlike the surrounding poor, acidic, and nutrient-leached soils typical of the rainforest region, Terra Preta is rich in nutrients, particularly phosphorus, nitrogen, and carbon, making it extremely fertile and productive.

ecology.question: What are the layers of vertical stratification in agroforestry systems?
answers: These typically include a canopy layer (tall trees), an understory layer (shorter trees and large shrubs), a shrub layer, a herbaceous layer (crops and ground cover plants), and sometimes a root layer (root crops) and a vine layer. Basically vertical stratification.

ecology.question: Photolithoautotroph ______

ecology.question: Random sampling
answers: A method where each member of a population has an equal chance of inclusion in a sample.

ecology.question: Stratified sampling
answers: A method where the population is divided into subgroups, and samples are taken from each subgroup

ecology.question: Systematic sampling
answers: A method where a sample is selected at regular intervals.

ecology.question: Simpson’s Index of 0.1 / Simpson’s Index of 0.7
answers: A community with an index of 0.1 has a high degree of dominance (lower biodiversity) while a community with an index of 0.7 has lower dominance (higher biodiversity)

ecology.question: Simpson’s Reciprocal Index of 1 / Simpson’s Reciprocal Index of 5
answers: A community with an reciprocal index of 1 has low diversity while an index of 5 has high diversity

ecology.question: Briefly explain two key differences between deciduous and coniferous trees.
answers:
There are several parameters of comparison between coniferous and deciduous trees. They include:

Wood Type
Deciduous trees have hardwood barks and are best for making furniture. But, coniferous trees produce softwood. Wood from coniferous trees is best for paper and matchbox production.

Fruits and Flowers
Deciduous trees produce colorful flowers and fruits. The trees flower during seasons when they have no leaves. But coniferous trees have no fruits or flowers. Instead, they produce needles and cones containing seeds.

Leaf Color
Deciduous trees change the color of their leaves during winter and autumn. The leaves change into yellow, orange, and red. However, it’s important to note that in some cases, tree leaves turning yellow may indicate specific issues, such as nutrient deficiencies or stress. Keeping a close eye on the color changes can help you address potential concerns and ensure the overall health of your trees.

Foliage Shape
Deciduous trees have broad foliage because they grow outwards. The broad foliage allows them to maximize sunlight absorption. Coniferous trees are cone-shaped because they grow upwards.

Weather Conditions in Existence
Deciduous trees are common in warm regions, but coniferous trees do well in cold tundra regions.

Shedding Leaves
Coniferous trees shed their leaves throughout the year. New leaves constantly replace the shed leaves. But deciduous trees shed their leaves during the autumn season.

ecology.question: Climate change and global warming are happening, accelerating, and portend major consequences for the Earth’s vibrantly profuse and luxuriant ecosystems. For each of the tundra, taiga, and deciduous forest biomes, briefly list one impact that any facet of climate change (e.g., species extinction) will have on them specifically.
answers:
Tundra:
A warmer climate could radically change tundra landscapes and what species are able to live in them. Warming creates potential feedback loops that encourage further destabilization of tundra ecosystems. The release of methane from deteriorating permafrost, for example, feeds the thawing cycle, while higher temperatures drive the growth of shrubs, which can change soil temperature and prevent snow from reflecting out heat.

Thriving shrubs also crowd out lichen, an important food source for caribou and other animals. Warmer tundras could also see increased risk of wildfires and drought—scientists have documented a significant disappearance of lakes in western Greenland between 1969 and 2017.

Taiga:
Climate change puts taigas in danger in different ways. Warming climate contributes to a partial thawing of the permafrost. Since this water has no place to drain, more area of the taiga is taken over by muskegs. Few trees take root.

Warming temperature also changes animal habitats. It pushes native species out and attracts non-native species. Animals such as the Siberian tiger are not adapted to warm weather. Its coat is too heavy, and it stores too much body fat to thrive in a temperate habitat. Non-native insects such as the bark beetle can infest trees such as spruce. Millions of these insects bore into the bark of trees, laying eggs. The infested trees die. Bark beetle infestations can kill entire forests and thousands of hectares of taiga.

Deciduous forests:

Climate change is causing dry regions to get drier and wet areas to turn wetter. Also, precipitation is tending to fall in heavier bursts. This is especially significant for temperate deciduous forests, as many lie in areas prone to severe winter weather. Increased frequency and intensity of ice storms are of particular concern, as ice accumulation harbors the potential to exert irreparable damage on hardwoods.

On the other end of the spectrum, some deciduous forests are beginning to experience an uptick in sustained droughts due to climate change, which adversely affects the health of many species, such as birch and beech, according to the Forest Ecology Network. Deciduous forests in the western United States, southern Europe, the Mediterranean, and northern China are especially vulnerable to increased droughts; these droughts can also spark fires that quickly destroy large swaths of forest. Drought aside, high temperatures may harm some deciduous forests -- such as those of the Mediterranean -- outright, as trees cannot photosynthesize effectively in extreme heat. In cooler regions, however, the warmer temperatures may enhance tree growth, so long as rainfall remains sufficient.

On the whole, these temperature-related climate changes affect the global distribution of deciduous forests, cause them to recede from their existing locations and migrate to new areas. For instance, in already arid regions which are becoming even drier, deciduous forests are starting to slowly vanish, turning to savanna. On the other hand, deciduous species are invading high northern latitudes once covered by coniferous boreal forests. Along with the shifting deciduous forests, the animals and forest floor plants which inhabit them also shift.

ecology.question: Your team is conducting a field study in the tundra. On your first day there, you are really excited to get started, so you immediately begin setting up your gear. As you work, one of the interns working with your group asks about what sampling technique should be used for what particular circumstance. Provide a scenario/example for each of the following sampling techniques (using organisms that you would find in the tundra) and identify the advantages of each method.
answers:
a. Random sampling

This is where each member of the population is equally likely to be included.

For taking random samples of an area, use a random number table or random number generator to select numbers. Use pairs of numbers as x and y co-ordinates. You could use a meter ruler interval markings (e.g. to take vegetation samples in a saltmarsh) or grid references (e.g. to find random samples in an upland area).

Random sampling is used to select a sample that is unbiased. Within each area, every part of the area must have an equal chance of being chosen. Random sampling with quadrats is used to examine differences between contrasting habitats within an habitat. There are many possible questions that could be investigated in this way.

In each habitat you are investigating, mark out a 10m x 10m square on the ground by laying one tape measure 10m lengthways and a second tape measure 10m at right angles to the first. Use a random number table (or random number generator on a calculator) to select numbers from 1-10. Each pair of random numbers can be used as x and y co-ordinates, using the metre interval markings on each tape measure. Use these to locate the lower left hand corner of a frame quadrat or use a point quadrat. Take at least 10 quadrat samples in each area.

b. Stratified sampling

This is where a proportionate number of observations is taken from each part of the population.

Divide a habitat into zones which appear different and take samples from each zone. For example, if vegetation cover in an area of heathland is 60% heather and 40% gorse, for a stratified sample take 60% of the samples from within heather and 40% of the samples from within gorse.

c. Systematic sampling

Systematic sampling is used where the study area includes an environmental gradient. A transect is used to sample systematically along the environmental gradient. For example, every 10 meters along a line running from seashore inland across a sand dune system.

dynamic planet.question:
Yellowstone and Hawaii are both hotspots, but their eruption styles are very different. While
Hawaiian volcanoes produce effusive eruptions where the largest risks to populations are lava flows,
Yellowstone has the potential to form a large explosive eruption that could cause an ash cloud that
blankets much of the western United States. Why is this the case?
answers: The main reason is because the magma under Yellowstone is much more silica rich than the magma under Hawaii and so it is far more viscous, meaning the gasses will build up a higher pressure resulting in a more explosive eruption.

dynamic planet.question: Describe the process of the formation of a meandering stream.
answers: Meandering streams form due to a combination of erosion and deposition. Water flows faster on the outside of a bend, causing erosion and forming cut banks. Sediment is deposited on the inside of the bend, forming point bars. Over time, these processes cause the stream to meander across the floodplain.

dynamic planet.question: Define Porosity
answers: Porosity is the measure of the void spaces in a rock or sediment material.

dynamic planet.question: Define Permeability
answers: Permeability is the measure of the ability of a rock or sediment material to transmit fluids.

dynamic planet.question: Referring back to the definition you answered for permeability, what increases the permeability of a waterway?
answers: Larger pore sizes and well-connected pores increase the permeability of a waterway.

dynamic planet.question: Define Aquifers
answers: Aquifers are underground layers of rock or sediment that hold and transmit groundwater.

dynamic planet.question: Do aquifers have high or low porosity and permeability?
answers: Aquifers have high porosity and permeability.

dynamic planet.question: Define Aquitards
answers: Aquitards are underground layers of rock or sediment that restrict groundwater flow due to low permeability.

dynamic planet.question: Do aquitards have low or high porosity and permeability?
answers: Aquitards have low porosity and permeability.

dynamic planet.question: Define Sinuosity
answers: Sinuosity is the measure of how much a stream or river channel meanders, calculated as the channel length divided by the straight-line distance between two points.

dynamic planet.question: What are the differences between Permanent and Ephemeral Streams?
answers: Permanent streams flow continuously throughout the year due to a constant water source (like groundwater), while ephemeral streams flow only after rainfall events and dry up during dry periods.

dynamic planet.question: What is stream discharge and what is the formula for it?
answers: Stream discharge is the volume of water flowing past a point in a given time, usually measured in cubic meters per second (m³/s). The formula is Discharge (Q) = Area (A) * Velocity (V)

dynamic planet.question: Rivers are one of the reasons for shaping the Earth’s surface. It does this through Erosion, sediment transport and deposition. What is the dissolved load, suspended load, and bed load?
answers: Dissolved load is the material carried in solution. Suspended load is the fine-grained material (like silt and clay) carried within the water column. Bed load is the coarser material (like sand and gravel) that moves along the streambed through rolling, sliding, or bouncing.

dynamic planet.question: What is stream capacity and what is it controlled by?
answers: Stream capacity is the maximum amount of sediment a stream can transport at a given discharge. It is controlled by discharge, velocity, and channel characteristics.

dynamic planet.question: What is stream competence?
answers: Stream competence is the measure of the largest size of material that a stream can transport.

dynamic planet.question: Referring to Image 12a on the image sheet, what is the formula for discharge and how do you find it on a hydrograph?
answers: This question requires an image to answer. The formula for discharge is Discharge (Q) = Area (A) * Velocity (V). On a hydrograph, discharge is found on the y-axis.

dynamic planet.question: What is meant by the term ‘lag time’?
answers: Lag time is the time delay between the peak of rainfall and the peak of streamflow on a hydrograph.

dynamic planet.question: What effect does urbanization have on a hydrograph?
answers: Urbanization increases the peak discharge and reduces lag time on a hydrograph due to increased impervious surfaces and faster runoff.

dynamic planet.question: What does a ‘rising limb’ on a hydrograph indicate?
answers: A rising limb on a hydrograph indicates an increase in streamflow following a rainfall event.

dynamic planet.question: What is a recurrence interval?
answers: Recurrence interval is the average time between events of a given magnitude, such as floods, based on historical data.

dynamic planet.question: If a 100 year flood occurs on the Mississippi river in 2010, what is the probability that a flood of the same magnitude will occur in 2022?
answers: The probability of a 100-year flood occurring in any given year is 1%, regardless of past occurrences.

dynamic planet.question: What is percolation?
answers: Percolation is the downward movement of water through soil and rock due to gravity.

dynamic planet.question: Define cave
answers: A cave is a naturally formed underground void or cavity, typically large enough for a person to enter.

dynamic planet.question: Define Karst Landscape
answers: A Karst landscape is a terrain with distinctive landforms (like sinkholes, caves, and disappearing streams) formed by the dissolution of soluble rocks like limestone.

dynamic planet.question: What is the difference between cover subsidence and and cover collapse?
answers: Cover subsidence sinkholes occur gradually as the soil or sediment above a void slowly sinks or compacts, while cover collapse sinkholes occur abruptly when the surface material collapses into a void below.

dynamic planet.question: What is the process for a cover collapse sinkhole?
answers: Cover collapse sinkholes form when a subsurface cavity develops, usually in soluble rock, and the overlying sediment or soil collapses into the void suddenly.

dynamic planet.question: How are drainage basins formed?
answers: Drainage basins are formed by the network of streams and rivers that drain into a single outlet point, which is influenced by topography and geology.

dynamic planet.question: What is the main difference between a braided stream channel and an anastomose channel?
answers: Braided streams consist of multiple interconnected channels separated by bars or islands, while anastomosing streams have multiple, relatively stable channels separated by vegetated floodplains.

dynamic planet.question: Define potential evapotranspiration and describe at least three parameters that it depends on.
answers: Potential evapotranspiration is the amount of water that could be evaporated and transpired under ideal conditions with unlimited water supply. It depends on parameters such as temperature, solar radiation, wind speed, and humidity.

dynamic planet.question: Which of the following are reasons for removing dams from rivers (mark all that are correct)?

answers: A pingo is a dome-shaped hill or mound that has a core of ice, and it is found in periglacial regions.

dynamic planet.question: Define Permafrost:
answers: Permafrost is a subsurface layer of soil that remains frozen for two or more years.

dynamic planet.question: Define Epilimnion and Hypolimnion
answers: The epilimnion is the warmer, surface layer of a lake, and the hypolimnion is the colder, deeper layer of a lake.

dynamic planet.question: What separates the epilimnion from the hypolimnion?
answers: The thermocline, or metalimnion, separates the epilimnion from the hypolimnion, which is a zone of rapid temperature change.

dynamic planet.question: Which lake zone is sometimes referred to as the “lake’s digestive system,” as bacteria decompose organic matter in this area?
answers: The benthic zone is referred to as the 'lake’s digestive system' because bacteria decompose organic matter here.

dynamic planet.question: What term describes the average time that it takes to completely renew the water volume of a lake?
answers: The term used to describe the average time that it takes to completely renew the water volume of a lake is residence time or water renewal time.

How does a lake form from a glacier?
answers:
Near the end of the last glacial period, glaciers began to retreat. A retreating glacier often left behind large deposits of ice in hollows between drumlins or
hills. As the ice age ended, these melted to create lakes.

dynamic planet.question: What is the role of the stagnation zone beneath a lake?
answers:
In seepage lakes that are surrounded by the water table on all sides, the stagnation zone leads to upward seepage through the lake bottom. As long as the
stagnation zone is present, the lake will never lose water through the bottom OR leads to upward seepage through the lake bottom

dynamic planet.question: Define “critical zone”.

dynamic planet.question: What type of lake will Horseshoe Bend become over time? How are these lakes formed?

dynamic planet.question: Why is it difficult to farm in an area of Karst topography, even if soil quality is good and rainfall is adequate?

What differentiates aquifers, aquitards, aquicludes, and aquifuges?
Describe the sediment forms that characterize each of these geological formations
answers:
Aquifers are permeable formations that can both store water and yield water, made up of sand, gravel, etc. Aquitards are partially permeable
formations that can store water and slowly yield it, made up of materials like sandy clay. Aquicludes are impermeable formations that can store water but not yield it, made up of hard
clays. Aquifuges are impermeable formations that can neither store water nor yield it, made up of compact rocks such as basalt or granite.

dynamic planet.question: Define stream capacity, stream competence, and stream load.
answers: Stream capacity is the total amount of sediment a stream can carry. Stream competence is the size of the largest particle a stream can carry. Stream load is the total amount of sediment a stream is actually carrying.

dynamic planet.question: List 3 forms of Karst topography.
Describe how Karst topography forms and write a chemical equation involved in the process.
answers: Karst topography forms when slightly acidic water dissolves soluble rocks, mainly limestone. The chemical equation is: CO2 + H2O -> H2CO3, H2CO3 + CaCO3 -> Ca2+ + 2HCO3-

dynamic planet.question: Identify the difference between an aquiclude and an aquifer.
answers: An aquiclude is an impermeable layer that restricts water flow, while an aquifer is a permeable layer that allows water to flow and be stored.

dynamic planet.question: Identify the difference between a water table well and an artesian well.
answers: A water table well is a well that is dug into an unconfined aquifer and is supplied by the water table. An artesian well taps into a confined aquifer, where water rises under pressure and without pumping.

dynamic planet.question: Fill in the blanks in the following statements. Make sure to read the statements carefully. ____ percent of the water on earth is freshwater. ____ percent of the earth’s freshwater is stored in ice sheets and glaciers, ____ percent in groundwater, and ____ percent as available freshwater. Of the available freshwater, ____percent is stored as lakes, ____ percent in the atmosphere, and ____ percent in rivers and streams.

Fill in the blanks of the following statements. Make sure to read the statements carefully. The finest particles of a stream’s load that are in solution are known as _________ load. The fine particles that travel along the stream are known as _________ load. The remaining, heavier particles that move along the base of the stream are known as _________ load.
Define aggradation and degradation (in a river context).
answers: Aggradation is the process of a river bed rising due to sediment deposition, while degradation is the process of a river bed lowering due to erosion.

dynamic planet.question: Lakes can be described as oligotrophic, mesotrophic, or eutrophic, depending on certain conditions. For the following classifications, describe key characteristics of the condition. a. Oligotrophic: b. Mesotrophic: c. Eutrophic:
answers: a. Oligotrophic: Nutrient-poor, clear water, low biological productivity. b. Mesotrophic: Moderate nutrient levels, moderate biological productivity, some algae. c. Eutrophic: Nutrient-rich, high biological productivity, high algae, often low oxygen levels.

dynamic planet.question: Explain how eutrophication occurs and identify two anthropogenic factors that contribute to these conditions.
answers: Eutrophication occurs when excessive nutrients enter a water body, leading to algal blooms, which decompose and deplete oxygen, causing fish death. Two anthropogenic factors are agricultural runoff (fertilizers) and wastewater discharge.

dynamic planet.question: In a meandering river, the water moves at different speeds depending on the position in the cross-section. a. Where in the cross section do the highest speeds occur? b.  Where in the cross section do the lowest speeds occur?
answers: a. The highest speeds occur near the surface and center of the channel. b. The lowest speeds occur along the riverbed and the banks

dynamic planet.question: Explain why the locations of highest and lowest water velocity as identified by the previous question occur the way they do (your answer should consider the relationship between discharge and water velocity).
answers: Water velocity is highest in the center of the channel and surface of the water because of less friction with the riverbed and banks, and water discharge is distributed. Velocity is lowest at the bed and sides due to friction slowing the flow.

dynamic planet.question: Identify the most important drawback to using Hack’s stream order, as opposed to Shreve’s or Strahler’s.
answers: Hack’s stream order doesn't account for streams forming between the junction of two streams of the same order. Therefore, it fails to account for all the flows in a watershed.

dynamic planet.question: Describe the characteristics of the following stream stages: a. Youthful b. Mature c. Old Age
answers: a. Youthful: High gradient, fast-flowing, v-shaped valley, few tributaries, straight channel. b. Mature: Moderate gradient, slower flow, broad valley, many tributaries, some meandering. c. Old Age: Low gradient, slow-flowing, wide floodplain, many meanders, oxbow lakes.

dynamic planet.question: Describe how groundwater depletion occurs and two negative consequences.
answers: Groundwater depletion occurs when the rate of water extraction exceeds the rate of recharge. Two negative consequences are land subsidence and decreased well yields.

dynamic planet.question: Suppose a vertical source of pollution occurs at the star in the previous image. Is the river safe to drink from? Why or why not?
answers: No, because pollution in groundwater contaminates a water source and since they are interconnected, the surface water also will be unsafe.

dynamic planet.question: Write the formula for a watershed’s drainage density.
answers: Drainage Density = Total stream length / Watershed area

dynamic planet.question: Write the formula for a stream’s discharge.
answers: Discharge = Stream width * Stream depth * Stream velocity

dynamic planet.question: Define hydraulic head.
answers: Hydraulic head is the energy that drives groundwater flow, measured as the height of the water column above a reference point.

dynamic planet.question: Fill in the blanks of the following statements: a. The Horton law of stream numbers states that there exists a ________ relationship between the number of streams of a given order Nw and the corresponding order, w. The parameter of this relationship is the ________ Ratio, RB. b. The Horton law of stream lengths states that there exists a ________ relationship between the average length of streams of a given order and the corresponding order, w. The parameter of this relationship is the so-called ________ Ratio, RL. c. The Horton law of stream areas states that there exists a ________ relationship between the average area drained by streams of a given order and the corresponding order w. The parameter of this relationship is the so-called ________ Ratio, RA.
answers: a. inverse, bifurcation b. direct, length c. direct, area

dynamic planet.question: Identify if the following clast types/sizes would be eroded, transported, or deposited in the following river environments. a. Sand in a 0.5cm/s river b. Clay in a 500cm/s river c. 1cm clast in a 1m/s river
answers: a. Deposited, b. Eroded/Transported, c. Transported

dynamic planet.question: What is the name of the diagram required to answer the previous question?
Define endorheic and exorheic lakes.
answers: Endorheic lakes are lakes that have no outlet to the ocean and drain into landlocked basins. Exorheic lakes are lakes that drain into oceans or seas through rivers and streams.

dynamic planet.question: Calculate the probability that a hundred year flood occurs at least once in a 15 year interval. Show your work.
answers: P(100yr flood in 1 yr) = 1/100 = 0.01, P(no 100yr flood in 1 yr) = 1 - 0.01 = 0.99, P(no 100yr flood in 15 yrs) = 0.99^15, P(at least 1 100yr flood in 15 yrs) = 1 - 0.99^15 = 0.139 = 13.9%

dynamic planet.question: Name and define the three ratios soil moisture can expressed as.
answers: Saturation (all pores are filled with water), Field Capacity (the amount of water a soil can hold against gravity), Wilting Point (the point where plants can no longer extract water from the soil).

dynamic planet.question: Consider a stream that travels from a location of high elevation (ie. upper reaches), then to moderate elevation (ie. middle reaches), then to lower elevation (ie. lower reaches). Describe the a) slope, b) water velocity, c) valley shape, d) depth, e) stream order, and f) amount of discharge at each reach.
answers: a. high, medium, low; b. fast, medium, slow; c. V-shaped, broad, flat; d. shallow, medium, deep; e. low, medium, high; f. low, medium, high

dynamic planet.question: Describe the process of fracking.
answers: Fracking is a process of injecting high-pressure fluid (water, sand, and chemicals) into shale rock formations to extract trapped oil and natural gas.

dynamic planet.question: Is fracking harmful to the environment? If so, why? If not, why not?
answers: Yes, fracking is harmful to the environment because it can contaminate groundwater, induce earthquakes, cause air pollution, and contribute to climate change.

dynamic planet.question: The three sections of this test are named. What are these three names describing?
answers: They describe the three layers of a stratified lake: epilimnion, metalimnion, and hypolimnion.

dynamic planet.question: Dr. Ellis proposes, as a solution to CO2 storage after sequestration from the atmosphere, that we could store CO2 in deep saline aquifers. What features about these deep saline aquifers make them good for CO2 storage?
answers: Deep saline aquifers have large storage capacity, porous and permeable rocks, and are sealed by low-permeability caprock. They are also usually located far from freshwater sources.

botany.question: Explain the eﬀects in thylakoid ph that would be observed from knocking out cytochrome b6f (1.5 pt), and altering the amino acid sequence of ferredoxin so it binds to plastocyanin more preferentially than plastoquinone.(1.5 pt)
answers: Knocking out cytochrome b6f would result in a lower proton concentration in the thylakoid lumen, thus a higher thylakoid pH. Changing the amino acid sequence of ferredoxin to have a higher affinity for plastocyanin would block the ETC before it reaches NADPH. This would ultimately lower the proton concentration inside the thylakoid, thus a higher pH.

answers: Modified fiber separation test: After incubation, shake vigorously and separate individual fibers using a microscope, record the number of fibers released in the test tube for each fiber at 12, 24 and 36 hours.

botany.question: In the previous question, why was the modification of the standard version created, and how does it affect the results of the study? What other methods of standard research could further improve this study and how?(Be as specific as possible)
answers: The modification was necessary because the standard test involves physically pulling the fibers, which doesn't quantify fiber separation; Modified test will more precisely measure the effect of the enzyme on fibers. A standard measurement like tensile strength would show how much enzymatic retting degrades the fiber as well, and a SEM analysis would help visualize the fibers.

botany.question: What type of retting did this study evaluate? What are the other two main types of retting? Describe the general process of all three and list 2 benefits and 2 disadvantages for each compared to the other two(only one disadvantage is needed for the type of retting this study evaluated).
answers: Enzymatic retting; Other types of retting are water and chemical. Water retting involves soaking in water to promote microbial degradation and is slow, can pollute water, can over-rett, but has good fiber quality and is low cost. Chemical retting uses chemicals to degrade pectin, it is fast, and can be done on a large scale, but it has higher cost and weaker fibers. Enzymatic retting is a controlled process with specific enzymes, less pollution, more specific, good quality, but enzyme cost and time it takes to prepare/optimize the enzymes is a drawback.

experimental design.question: Statement addresses the experiment including variables
answers: Statement clearly identifies the experiment being conducted and its independent and dependent variables. Not a yes/no question.

experimental design.question: Statement predicts a relationship between the independent and dependent variables
answers: The hypothesis should predict how changing the independent variable will affect the dependent variable.

experimental design.question: Statement gives specific direction to the prediction(s) (i.e., a stand is taken)
answers: The hypothesis makes a clear and specific prediction about the direction of the relationship (e.g. increasing X will increase Y).

experimental design.question: A rationale is given for the hypothesis.
answers: The hypothesis is explained logically using scientific principles or previous knowledge.

experimental design.question: IV Correctly identified and operationally defined
answers: The independent variable, the variable that is being changed, is explicitly defined and made measurable.

experimental design.question: Levels of IV given
answers: The different specific values the independent variable will have in the experiment are identified.

experimental design.question: DV Correctly identified and operationally defined
answers: The dependent variable, the variable that is being measured, is explicitly defined and made measurable.

experimental design.question: First CV correctly identified and relevant
answers: A control variable, an extraneous factor that will be kept constant, is identified and it has an impact on the experiment.

experimental design.question: Second CV correctly identified and relevant
answers: A second control variable, an extraneous factor that will be kept constant, is identified and it has an impact on the experiment.

experimental design.question: Third CV correctly identified and relevant
answers: A third control variable, an extraneous factor that will be kept constant, is identified and it has an impact on the experiment.

experimental design.question: First Constant correctly identified and relevant
answers: A constant, an inherent attribute that will stay the same through the experiment, is identified and is relevant to the experiment.

experimental design.question: SOC logically identified for the experiment
answers: The 'standard of comparison', a control group or value, is chosen as a baseline or reference for measuring effect.

experimental design.question: Reason given for selection of SOC
answers: The rationale for why the chosen 'standard of comparison' is appropriate and logical to use.

experimental design.question: All materials used are listed and quantified
answers: All materials used in the experiment are listed and the exact amount or quantity of each is specified.

experimental design.question: No unused or extra materials are listed
answers: Only the materials directly used in the experiment are in the materials list, nothing that was available but was not used.

experimental design.question: Procedure is presented in list form
answers: The experiment's steps are explained step by step, clearly written with a list or similar formatting

experimental design.question: Procedure is in a logical sequence
answers: The procedure steps are in the order they need to be done and are easy to follow.

experimental design.question: Steps for repeated trials are included
answers: The procedure includes instructions on how to conduct multiple trials to test and confirm results.

experimental design.question: Multiple diagrams of setup are provided
answers: More than one visual representation of the experimental setup is given, clarifying each stage of the experimental process.

experimental design.question: All diagrams are appropriately labeled
answers: Each diagram of the experimental setup is clearly labelled and identifiable, with the parts identified and what they are meant to be doing

experimental design.question: Procedure detailed enough to repeat experiment accurately
answers: The procedure is explained clearly enough that someone else could replicate the exact same procedure and results.

experimental design.question: Observations about procedure provided
answers: Observations of the steps in the experiment, any difficulties or other information learned during the execution is recorded

experimental design.question: Observations about the results provided
answers: Detailed observations of the outcome or results of the experiment, not only numerical, but including any difficulties and other observations about the results

experimental design.question: Observations given throughout the course of the experiment
answers: Observations are taken throughout the course of the experiment, recording what occurs throughout the experiment and not only at the very end.

experimental design.question: All raw data is provided
answers: All raw data from the trials of the experiment is included.

experimental design.question: Condensed data table with only the data to be graphed is provided
answers: A condensed data table includes data that will be used to construct the graph.

experimental design.question: Tables and columns labeled properly
answers: All tables and columns are clearly labelled so that each of their meanings are clear.

experimental design.question: All data has units
answers: Each data point recorded includes its proper units.

experimental design.question: Appropriate Graph is provided
answers: The graph is the correct kind to represent the data. (e.g, scatter plot for correlations)

experimental design.question: Graph properly titled and labeled
answers: The graph's axes and other important parts are all labeled with their proper names and units, and the graph has a descriptive title.

experimental design.question: Appropriate scale and units included
answers: The graph has a scale that allows all the data to be presented clearly, and all units are properly denoted

experimental design.question: Statistics of Central Tendency used (i.e., best fit, median, mode, mean)
answers: One of mean, median, or mode, is calculated to give a representation of the data's tendency.

experimental design.question: One example calculation is given for each statistic with units
answers: Each statistic used is described and has at least one example calculation, and the calculation includes units.

experimental design.question: Statistics of Variation are included (i.e., minimum, maximum, range, standard deviation)
answers: At least one of minimum, maximum, range, or standard deviation, is calculated to describe the distribution of data.

experimental design.question: Calculations are accurate
answers: The statistics are calculated without arithmetic or other math errors.

experimental design.question: Data is reported using correct significant figures
answers: Raw data is recorded to the correct amount of decimal places to represent the uncertainty of the measurement tools used.

experimental design.question: Graph completed using correct significant figures
answers: Graphs are generated with correct significant figures for points and axes.

experimental design.question: Statistics are reported using correct significant figures
answers: Statistics calculated are recorded to the correct number of decimal places to indicate the degree of precision.

experimental design.question: Claim completed logically for Variation
answers: A conclusion based on how the data set is spread out is stated logically and clearly.

experimental design.question: Evidence completed logically for Variation
answers: The specific data and analysis supporting the conclusion about the data's spread is cited logically and clearly

experimental design.question: Reasoning completed logically for Variation
answers: The reasoning behind the connection of data to the variation is clearly explained.

experimental design.question: Claim completed logically for Outliers
answers: A claim about presence and effect of outliers is logically stated.

experimental design.question: Evidence completed logically for Outliers
answers: Data is correctly cited to indicate the presence of outliers, and how it impacts data.

experimental design.question: Reasoning completed logically for Outliers
answers: The underlying reason for choosing how outliers are treated, and why they effect the data the way they do, is clear.

experimental design.question: Claim completed logically for Data Trend
answers: A claim about the general trend in the data set is clearly and logically stated.

experimental design.question: Evidence completed logically for Data Trend
answers: Specific data supporting the trend is logically cited and described

experimental design.question: Reasoning completed logically for Data Trend
answers: The rationale or connection of the trend to the underlying science is clearly explained.

experimental design.question: One specific error is identified and effect on results discussed.
answers: A potential specific error that occurred in the experiment is identified and how that error affected results is discussed.

experimental design.question: Second specific error is identified and effect on results discussed.
answers: A second potential specific error that occurred in the experiment is identified and how that error affected results is discussed.

experimental design.question: Hypothesis is re-stated
answers: The hypothesis from the beginning of the experiment is restated.

experimental design.question: Hypothesis Claim completed logically
answers: A claim about the hypothesis being supported or not is stated clearly and logically.

experimental design.question: Hypothesis Evidence completed logically
answers: The specific data that supports the claim about the hypothesis being supported is cited logically and clearly.

experimental design.question: Hypothesis Reasoning completed logically
answers: The reason that the data supports the hypothesis, based on scientific principles, is clearly stated.

experimental design.question: Suggestions to improve the experiment with rationale are provided
answers: Specific suggestions on how the experiment could be improved are provided, as well as reasoning behind the importance of these suggestions.

experimental design.question: Suggestions for practical applications of experiment are provided
answers: Suggestions on how the experiment could be applied to real-world situations are provided

experimental design.question: Suggestions for future experiments are provided
answers: Ideas are given about how to further investigate the questions asked by this experiment, with more details.

experimental design.question: Brief and well-organized
answers: The abstract is clear, concise, and contains all of the most important details in a well organized format.

experimental design.question: Contains the Statement of the Problem and Hypothesis
answers: The abstract includes the problem the experiment tried to solve and the hypothesis made.

experimental design.question: Describes the research procedure
answers: The abstract contains the most important steps in the process of the experiment.

experimental design.question: Includes major findings and conclusion
answers: The abstract has major numerical results and the conclusion drawn from them

Under what conditions do gases behave most ideally and why?
options: At lower temperatures and lower pressures; at lower temperatures, gases aren’t moving as fast, and therefore collide with the walls of their container less; at lower pressures, gases can occupy a larger proportion of the whole volume.

At lower temperatures and higher pressures; at lower temperatures, the gas particles aren’t moving as fast, and therefore collide with the walls of their container less; at higher pressures, the gas particles are able to be compressed more.

At higher temperatures and lower pressures; at higher temperatures, gas particles move more vigorously due to a higher average kinetic energy among particles, and can overcome IMFs; at lower pressures, gas particles do account for an appreciable amount of the whole volume.

At higher temperatures and lower pressures; at higher temperatures, gas particles move more vigorously due to a higher average kinetic energy distributed among the particles, such that they can overcome the IMFs between particles; at lower pressures, gas particles are at greater distances from one another, and account for a lesser proportion of the total volume, and are more easily compressible.

it's about time.question: What is another name for water clocks?
What is the difference between inflow and outflow water clocks?
answers: Inflow clocks measure time by the amount of water that flows into a container, while outflow clocks measure time by the amount of water that flows out of a container.

it's about time.question: What was the first historical timekeeping device?
Explain how candle clocks were used to measure time.
answers: Candle clocks used the rate at which a candle burned to measure time, with markings along the candle to indicate time intervals. Candles could also be used with different burn rates to measure different intervals of time.
